awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Neuroendocrine Modulation of Circannual Rhythms in Mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
Predicting how species might alter their annual timing in response to rapid environmental change, including changes in climate, is constrained by insufficient knowledge of the endogenous mechanisms animals use to keep time, the cues used to adjust timing, and the extent to which programmed seasonal cycles are physiologically malleable or plastic. This project investigates the mechanisms that underlie plasticity in the seasonal induction of the neuroendocrine signals that trigger the termination of hibernation and the onset of reproduction in ground squirrels. Unlike most mammals, ground squirrels spontaneously become reproductively competent in constant darkness, without the stimulus of a changing photoperiod. As such, ground squirrels are an ideal organism for studies examining non-photoperiodic control of reproductive timing. Establishing the neuroendocrine mechanisms responsible for transitions between life-history stages will identify target genes for monitoring adaptive genetic responses to environmental change. This investigation integrates research and learning by training graduate students in ecophysiology and neurophysiology, providing opportunities for undergraduates to participate in laboratory experiments. The project also includes outreach to Alaska Native and American Indian high school students and undergraduates for inclusion in research and aims to increase K-12 students' understanding of and engagement in research by participating in Teacher Research Experience programs.

In hibernating mammals, a precise integration must occur between the central nervous system signaling cascades controlling thermoregulation through the termination of torpor and the subsequent activation of the reproductive axis; however, the neuroendocrine modulators that regulate these changes and how they are integrated are unknown. In seasonally breeding, photoperiodic vertebrates, the pars tuberalis (PT) of the pituitary plays an essential role in the timing of annual cycles, as it alters hypothalamic thyroid hormone availability by secreting thyroid stimulating hormone in a light- or melatonin-sensitive manner, which acts on neighboring hypothalamic deiodinase expressing cells. The PT thyrotrophs themselves are now considered strong candidates for circannual timer cells, driving a thyroid-dependent seasonal physiology. This research tests the hypothesis that, in the absence of any photic cues, the termination of torpor and onset of reproduction are triggered by spontaneous changes in hypothalamic thyroid status driven by activation of thyrotroph cells in the PT. Additionally, the project tests the hypothesis that plasticity in timing is driven by temperature-induced changes in hypothalamic deiodinase activity and/or through effects on downstream targets of the triiodothyronine signaling pathway that occur independent of the PT.

por.por_cntn:
Programmed dormancy is an adaptive trait to highly seasonal environments expressed by a variety of animals across the tree of life. Within mammals, hibernation is a phylogenetically ancient and taxonomically widespread trait, characterized by prolonged periods of metabolic suppression and low body temperature interrupted by brief periodic ?arousal? episodes of unknown function. A critical unanswered question in dormancy research is how the endogenous ?lock? put in place during the initiation of hibernation is released, allowing animals to either spontaneously end hibernation, or respond to cues that signal the return of favorable environmental conditions. Our project findings demonstrate previously undetected physiological dynamism in the brain in the hibernating state and show that seasonal circuitry in the hypothalamus & pituitary are gradually reactivated during short arousal bouts over the course of the winter hibernation season. Reactivation of these seasonal circuits, in turn, stimulates the reproductive axis, resulting in sex-specific steroid production and sex-differences in the termination of hibernation in spring.

 

More specifically, as part of our project we show activation of the retrograde thyrotropin /deiodinase/ tri-iodothyronine (T3) signaling pathway in the pituitary and hypothalamus during hibernation, coupled with cellular remodeling of hypothalamic glial cells called tanycytes, and activation of the reproductive axis in ground squirrels. Further, we demonstrate that forcing animals to end hibernation prematurely, via exposure to high ambient temperatures, alters hypothalamic T3 signaling. Finally, exposure to ecologically relevant levels of warming in late winter resulted in sex-specific responses ? males showed upregulation of thyrotropin and gonadal growth, whereas females did not. While it has long been known that an internal calendar (circannual clock) in hibernators regulates the onset of timing of hibernation, body mass and the activity of the reproductive system, our study indicates that brain activity and neuroendocrine pathways are being altered by this circannual clock across the hibernation season ? given that transcription and translation are globally suppressed during torpor, this suggests that periodic arousals are being used to support seasonal reprogramming of neuroendocrine circuits.

 

As part of this project, we integrated research and learning by training 1 post-doctoral fellow, 6 graduate students, and 7 undergraduates in ecophysiology and neurophysiology ? two graduate thesis research projects were directly funded through this project. As part of this study, we worked with the PolarTREC program (administered by the Arctic Research Consortium of the U.S. [ARCUS]), and provided a professional development opportunity for Jennifer Baldacci, an American 8th grade science and high school biology/chemistry teacher from the International School in Basel, Switzerland. We hosted Ms. Baldacci for 3 weeks during the summer at Toolik Field Station in northern Alaska where she gained hands-on experience in field research in the Arctic. Ms. Baldacci worked with PI Williams to disseminate information from her polar research experiences to her classroom as well as to classrooms throughout the United States and abroad. Using data from this project, Ms. Baldacci also produced two lesson plans that teach high school students to evaluate, manipulate, and analyze hibernation data to evaluate hypotheses. Information was also disseminated to the general public in an online blog, through PolarConnect video conference events, through a documentary short film, and via online videos produced by PolarTREC Teachers. Finally, members of the Williams lab engaged K-12 students by conducting outreach at two elementary schools and two high schools in the Fairbanks North Star Borough School District.
